Definition: Analytics is the process of using data to make decisions.
Renters insurance is an insurance policy that covers the contents of an apartment or house that you are renting.
An insurance policy that covers damage to your vehicle, damage to other vehicles in the accident, as well as medical expenses of those injured in the accident.

Causalty insurance is a form of liability insurance providing coverage for negligent acts and omissions. examples include workers compensation, errors and omissions, fidelity, crime, glass, boiler, and various malpractice coverages.
The duration of an insurance contract
An insurance claim is the compensation provided by the insurer for incurred hurt, loss, or damage that is covered by the policy.
Homeowners insurance is an insurance policy that covers the contents and property of a building that is owned by you or a friend.

Property insurance is a policy that protects the insured against loss or damage to real or personal property. the cause of loss might be  fire, lightening, business interruption, loss of rents, glass breakage, tornado, windstorm, hail, water damage, explosion, riot, civil commotion, rain, or damage from aircraft or vehicles.

Non-life insurance is any type of insurance where payments are not based on the death (or survivorship) of a named insured. examples include automobile, homeowners, and so on. also known as property and casualty or general insurance.
Life insurance is a contract where the insurer promises to pay upon the death of an insured person. the person being paid is the beneficiary.
Insurance purchased by a person

Loss adjustment expenses are costs to the insurer that are directly attributable to settling a claims. for example, the cost of an adjuster is someone who assess the claim cost or a lawyer who becomes involve in settling an insurer's legal obligation on a claim
Unallocated loss adjustment expenses are costs that can only be indirectly attributed to claim settlement; for example, the cost of an office to support claims staff
Allocated loss adjustment expenses, sometimes known by the acronym alea, are costs that can be directly attributed to settling a claim; for example, the cost of an adjuster
Underwriting is the process where the company makes a decision as to whether or not to take on a risk.

A loss reserve is an estimate of liability indicating the amount the insurer expects to pay for claims that have not yet been realized. this includes losses incurred but not yet reported (ibnr) and those claims that have been reported claims that haven't been paid (known by the acronym rbns for reported but not settled).
Risk classification is the process of grouping policyholders into categories, or classes, where each insured in the class has a risk profile that is similar to others in the class.
The process of determining the cost of an insurance policy based on the actual loss experience determined as an adjustment to the initial premium payment.
Claims adjustment is the process of determining coverage, legal liability, and settling claims.
Claims leakage respresents money lost through claims management inefficiencies.
An adjuster is a person who investigates claims and recommends settlement options based on estimates of damage and insurance policies held.
A dividend is the refund of a portion of the premium paid by the insured from insurer surplus.
Indemnification is the compensation provided by the insurer.

Rating variables are the components of an insurance pricing formula. they can include numeric variables (like values, revenue, or area) and classification variables (like location, type of vehicle, or type of occupancy.)
Count random variables that represent the number of claims
The amount, or size, of each payment for an insured event
A function that gives the probability that a discrete random variable is exactly equal to some value
The chance that the random variable is less than or equal to x, as a function of x
Average
The rth moment of a list is the average value of the random variable raised to the rth power
The probability that the random variable takes on a value greater than a number x
The mgf of random variable n is defined the expectation of exp(tn), as a function of t
For a random variable n, its pgf is defined as the expectation of s^n, as a function of s
The convex hull of a set of points x is the smallest convex set that contains x
The formation of different premiums for the same coverage based on each homogeneous group's characteristics.

A random variable has a binomial distribution (with parameters m and q) if it is the number of "successes" in a fixed number m of independent random trials, all of which have the same probability q of resulting in "success."
Outcomes whose unit can take on only two possible states, traditionally labeled as 0 and 1
The addition of m independent random variables

A discrete probability distribution that expresses the probability of a given number of events occurring in a fixed interval of time or space if these events occur with a known constant rate and independently of the time since the last event
The number of successes until we observe the rth failure in independent repetitions of an experiment with binary outcomes
The presence of greater variability (statistical dispersion) in a data set than would be expected based on a given statistical model
There was less variation in the data than predicted
The poisson, binomial and negative binomial distributions
The possible value of the parameter for which the chance of observing the data largest
The largest and smallest value of the function within a given range

In some situations, when independent random variables are added, their properly normalized sum tends toward a normal distribution even if the original variables themselves are not normally distributed.
A root-finding algorithm which produces successively better approximations to the roots of a real-valued function
Resistant to errors in the results, produced by deviations from assumptions
In regression, the explanatory variable is the one that is supposed to "explain" the other.
A set of statistical processes for estimating the relationships among variables
Units of exposure that face approximately the same expected frequency and severity of loss.
A count distribution with probabilities satisfying p_k/p_{k-1}=a+b/k, for some some constants a and b and k>=2
Zero modification of a count distribution such that it assigns zero probability to zero count
A deterministic distribution and takes only a single value
A linear combination of points where all coefficients are non-negative and sum to 1
A real-valued function defined on an interval is called convex if the line segment between any two points on the graph of the function lies above or on the graph.

The probability distribution of a random variable that is derived from a collection of other random variables as follows: first, a random variable is selected by chance from the collection according to given probabilities of selection, and then the value of the selected random variable is realized
The chi-squared distribution with k degrees of freedom is the distribution of a sum of the squares of k independent standard normal random variables
The goodness of fit of a statistical model describes how well it fits a set of observations.
A statistical test applied to sets of categorical data to evaluate how likely it is that any observed difference between the sets arose by chance
The multinomial distribution models the probability of counts for rolling a k-sided die n times
Aggregate claims, or total claims observed in the time period
Insurance that compensates an insured for loss due to legal liability towards others
A weighted average of other distributions, which may be continuous or discrete
Random variable which can take infinitely many values in its specified domain
The kth moment of a random variable x is the average (expected) value of x^k
The kth central moment of a random variable x is the expected value of (x-its mean)^k
Measure of the symmetry of a distribution, 3rd central moment/standard deviation^3
Measure of the peaked-ness of a distribution, 4th central moment/standard deviation^4
Average
A single parameter continous probability distribution that is defined by its rate parameter
Two variables are independent if conditional information given about one variable provides no information regarding the other variable
The pth percentile of a random variable x is the smallest value x_p such that the probability of not exceeding it is p%
A common distribution used in chi-square tests for determining goodness of fit of observed data to a theorized distribution
A distribution with thinner tails than the benchmark exponential distribution
A heavy-tailed and positively skewed distribution with 2 parameters
Ratio of the probability density function and the survival function: f(x)/s(x), and represents an instantaneous probability within a small time frame
A positively skewed continuous distribution with 2 parameters that can have an increasing or decreasing hazard function depending on the shape parameter

Term: Generalized Beta distribution of the second kind
Definition: A 4-parameter flexible distribution that encompasses many common distributions
Probability distribution defined by a fixed set of parameters
A function or method that turns one distribution into another
A transformation technique that involves finding the cdf of the transformed distribution through its relation with the original cdf
A transformation technique that involves finding the pdf of the transformed distribution through its relation with the original pdf using inverse functions
A transformation technique that uses moment generating functions properties to determine the mgf of a linear combination of variables
A heavy-tailed, positively skewed 2-parameter continuous distribution such that the natural log of the random variable is normally distributed with the same parameter values
A dataset consisting of failure times for failed units and run times for units still functioning
A transformation type that involves raising a random variable to a power
A transformation type that involves raising a random variable in the exponent
Proportion weight given to each subpopulation in a mixture
A dataset where the subpopulations are represented by separate distinct distributions
A mixture distribution with a finite k number of subpopulations
A mixture distribution with an infinite number of subpopulations, where the mixing parameter is itself a continuous distribution
A probability distribution that applies to a subpopulation satisfying the condition
A probability distribution independent of any another imposed conditions
A probability distribution assigned prior to observing additional data
A distribution with the property that multiplying all values by a constant leads to the same distribution family with only the scale parameter changed
Situation where an insured is more likely to be risk seeking if they do not bear sufficient consequences for a loss
Amount insurer pays when a loss occurs and can be 0
Amount insurer pays given a payment is needed and is greater than 0
Values below a threshold d are not ignored but converted to 0
Values below a threshold d are not reported and unknown
% decrease of the expected payment by the insurer as a result of the deductible
Insurer pays nothing for losses below the deductible, but pays the full amount for any loss above the deductible
Policy limit, or maximum contractual financial obligation of the insurer for a loss
Insurance provided to groups of people to take advantage of lower administrative costs vs. individual policies
Multiplicative factor applied to a distribution to account for the impact of inflation, typically (1+rate)
Party that is transferring the risk to a reinsurer
Contract where an insurer pays all claims up to a specified amount and then the reinsurer pays claims in excess of stated reinsurance deductible
Maximum amount payable by the primary insurer in a reinsurance arrangement
Values above a threshold u are not ignored but converted to u
A transaction where the primary insurer buys insurance from a re-insurer who will cover part of the losses and/or loss adjustment expenses of the primary insurer
Statistical method used to derive the parameter values from data that maximize the probability of observing the data given the parameters
Data bucketed into categories with ranges, such as for use in histograms or frequency tables
Asymptotic properties of a distribution as the amount of data increases towards infinity
Variability of the distribution of an estimator as the amount of data increases towards infinity
Statistical method used to approximate the asymptotic variance for a function based on parameters whose asymptotic variance can be determined
Natural log of the likelihood function
Matrix where the (i,j)^th element represents the covariance between the ith and jth random variables
Data where each individual observation is known, and no values are censored, truncated, or grouped
Distributional assumptions made on the population from which the data is drawn, with properties defined using parameters.
No distributional assumptions are made on the population from which the data is drawn.
How the data is obtained from the population and what data is observed.
An estimator that has no bias, that is, the expected value of an estimator equals the parameter being estimated.

The plug-in principle or analog principle of estimation proposes that population parameters be estimated by sample statistics which have the same property in the sample as the parameters do in the population.
A categorical variable that has only two groups. the numerical values are usually taken to be one to indicate the presence of an attribute, and zero otherwise. another name for a binary variable.

The empirical distribution is a non-parametric estimate of the underlying distribution of a random variable. it directly uses the data observations to construct the distribution, with each observed data point in a size-n sample having probability 1/n.
The 25th percentile; the number such that approximately 25% of the data is below it.
The 75th percentile; the number such that approximately 75% of the data is below it.
The q-th quantile is the point(s) at which the distribution function is equal to q, i.e. the inverse of the cumulative distribution function.
A quantile obtained by linear interpolation between two empirical quantiles, i.e. data points.
A small positive constant that defines the width of the steps and the degree of smoothing.
A nonparametric estimator of the density function of a random variable.
The tradeoff between model simplicity (underfitting; high bias) and flexibility (overfitting; high variance).
Procedures to assess the validity of a model
A plot that compares two models through their cumulative probabilities.
A plot that compares two models through their quantiles.
A measure used to assess how well a statistical model fits the data, usually by summarizing the discrepancy between the observations and the expected values under the model.
The estimation of population parameters by approximating parametric moments using empirical sample moments.
The estimation of population parameters by approximating parametric percentiles using empirical quantiles.
A 100p-th percentile is the number such that 100 times p percent of the data is below it.
A measure for assessing income inequality. it measures the discrepancy between the income and population distributions and is calculated from the lorenz curve.
The process of selecting a statistical model from a set of candidate models using data.
A dataset used for analysis and model development. also known as a training dataset.
A dataset used for model validation. also known as a test dataset.
A model validation procedure in which the data sample is partitioned into subsamples, where splits are formed by separately taking each subsample as the out-of-sample dataset.
The process of confirming that the proposed model is appropriate.
Repeatedly fitting models to a data set without a prior hypothesis of interest.
Preditive inference is the process of using past data observations to predict future observations.
A function of the likeliness of the parameters in a model, given the observed data.
A nonparametric estimator for the distribution function in the presence of grouped data.
A nonparametric estimator of the survival function in the presence of incomplete data. also known as the kaplan-meier estimator.
The number of observations that are active (not censored) at a specific point.
A nonparametric estimator of the cumulative hazard function in the presence of incomplete data.
An actuarial method of balancing an individual's loss experience and the experience in the overall portfolio to improve ratemaking estimates.
A type of statistical inference in which the model parameters and the data are random variables.
The distribution of new data, conditional on a base set of data, under the bayesian framework.

A technique for estimating parameters in linear regression. it is a standard approach in regression analysis to the approximate solution of overdetermined systems. in this technique, one determines the parameters that minimize the sum of squared differences between each observation and the corresponding linear combination of explanatory variables.
The class of numerical methods that use markov chains to generate draws from a posterior distribution.
A prior distribution in which the sum or integral of the distribution is not finite.
Another term for interval estimate. unlike a point estimate, it gives a range of reliability for approximating a parameter of interest.
Bayesian decision theory is the study of an agent's choices, which is informed by bayesian probability.
Distributions such that the posterior and the prior come from the same family of distributions.
A summary of the posterior distribution of parameters under the bayesian framework.
The distribution of the parameters prior to observing data under the bayesian framework.

A measure of the rating units for which rates are applied to determine the premium. for example, exposures may be measured on a per unit basis (e.g. a family with auto insurance under one contract may have an exposure of 2 cars) or per $1,000 of value (e.g. homeowners insurance).
Inflation is a sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services over a period of time.
A modeling approach for aggregate losses in which the loss from each individual contract is considered.
A modeling approach for aggregate losses in which the aggregate loss is represented in terms of a frequency distribution and a severity distribution.
Insurance coverage is the amount of risk or liability that is covered for an individual or entity by an insurance policy.
The random number of claims that occur under the collective risk model.
The randomly distributed amount of each loss under the collective risk model.

Given certain conditions, the arithmetic mean of a large number of replications of independent random variables, each with a finite mean and variance, will be approximately normally distributed, regardless of the underlying distribution.
A term life insurance policy is payable only if death of the insured occurs within a specified time, such as 5 or 10 years, or before a specified age.
A pure endowment is an insurance policy that is payable at the end of the policy period if the insured is still alive. if the insured has died, there is nothing paid in the form of benefits.
The set of all outcomes for a random variable following some distribution. for example, exponentially distributed random variable x has support x>0.
The convolution of probability distributions is the distribution corresponding to the addition of independent random variables.
A decomposition of the expected value of a random variable into conditional components. specifically, for random variables x and y, e(x) = e[e(x|y)].

A random variable follows a compound distribution if it is parameterized and contains at least one parameter that is itself a random variable. for example, the tweedie distribution is a compound distribution.

A compound distribution that is a poisson sum of gamma random variables. because it can accommodate a discrete probability mass at zero and a continuous positive component, it is suitable for modeling aggregate insurance claims.

A numerical parameter of a parametric distribution affecting the shape of a distribution rather than simply shifting it (as a location parameter does) or stretching/shrinking it (as a scale parameter does).

A numerical parameter of a parametric distribution that stretches/shrinks the distribution without changing its location or shape. the larger the scale parameter, the more spread out the distribution. the scale parameter is also the reciprocal of the rate parameter. for example, the normal distribution has scale parameter \sigma.
A set of distributions that represents a generalisation of the natural exponential family and also plays an important role in generalized linear models.

Commonly known by the acronym glm. an extension of the linear regression model where the dependent variable is a member of the linear exponential family. glm encompasses linear, binary, count, and long-tailed, regressions all as special cases.

A family of parametric distributions that are practical for modeling the underlying response variable in generalized linear models. this family includes the normal, bernoulli, poisson, and tweedie distributions as special cases, among many others.
A computerized statistical model that simulates the effects of various types of uncertainty.

The empirical distribution is a non-parametric estimate of the underlying distribution of a random variable. it directly uses the data observations to construct the distribution, with each observed data point in a size-n sample having probability 1/n.
A type of stochastic convergence for a sequence of random variables x_1,…, x_n that approaches some other distribution as n approaches \infty.
A policy limit is the maximum value covered by a policy.
The total amount of loss sustained before policy adjustments are made (i.e. before deductions are applied for coinsurance, deductibles, and/or policy limits.)
Due to policy modifications (e.g. deductibles), not all losses that occur result in payment. the per-loss basis considers every loss that occurs.
Due to policy modifications (e.g. deductibles), not all losses that occur result in payment. the per-payment basis which considers only the losses that result in some payment to the insured.

The memoryless property means that a given probability distribution is independent of its history and what has already elapsed. specifically, random variable x is memoryless if pr(x > s+t | x >= s) = pr(x > t). note that it does not mean x > s+t and x >= s are independent events.
The sample mean and sample sum of a random sample of n from a population will converge to a normal curve as the sample size n grows
A computer generation of various hypothetical conditions and outputs, based on the model structure provided
Algorithm that yields pseudo-randomized numbers calculated using a linear recursive relationship and a starting seed value
Values that appear random but can be replicated by formula

Samples a uniform number between 0 and 1 to represent the randomly selected percentile, then uses the inverse of the cumulative density function of the desired distribution to simulate from in order to find the simulated value from the desired distribution
Inverse function for the cumulative density function which takes a percentile value in [0,1] as the input, and outputs the corresponding value in the distribution
Largest value that is less than or equal to a specified subset of values/elements

Type of cash value life insurance where the policy's cash value is the excess of premium payments over the cost of insurance, accumulated with interest, with adjustable premiums and coverage over time
Type of life insurance whose face value and coverage term can vary depending upon the performance of underlying invested securities
How much an estimate can vary between samples
A continuous distribution that represents the distribution of the ratio of two independent normally random variables, where the denominator distribution has mean zero
A nonparametric statistical test used to determine if a data sample could come from a hypothesized continuous probability distribution
A method of sampling with replacement from the original dataset to create additional simulated datasets of the same size as the original
A statistical method where no assumption is made about the distribution of the population
A statistical method where a prior assumption is made about the distribution or model form
The difference between the expected value of an estimator and the parameter being estimated. bias is an estimation error that does not become smaller as one observes larger sample sizes.
If an estimator is known to be consistently biased in a manner, it can be corrected using a factor to be come less biased or unbiased
For a convex function f(x), f(expected value of x) <= expected value of f(x)
An estimator that uses the sample moments as the estimators for the population

Confidence interval for the parameter estimates determined using the actual percentile results from the bootstrap sampling approach, as every bootstrap sample has an associated parameter estimate(s) that can be ranked against the others

A type of validation method where the data is randomly split into k groups, and each of the k groups is held out as a test dataset in turn, while the other k-1 gropus are used for distribution or model fitting, with the process repeated k times in total
A special case of k-fold cross validation, where each single data point gets a turn in being the lone hold-out test data point, and n separate models in total are built and tested
To calculate an estimator, leave out each observation in turn, calculate the sample estimator statistic each time, and average over the n separate estimates

A sampling method that is used where the random sample is discarded if not within a certain pre-specified range [a, b] and is commonly used when the traditional inverse transform method cannot be easily used
Type of sampling method where values in the region of interest can be over-sampled or values outside the region of interest can be under-sampled
Ergodic theory studies the behavior of a dynamical system when it is allowed to run for an extended time
A stochastic (time dependent) process that satisfies memorylessness, meaning future predictions of the process can be made solely based on its present state and not the historical path
Any mathematical measure that is preserved by a function (the mean is an example)
Component (smaller, self-contained part of larger entity)

A markov chain monte carlo (mcmc) method for random sampling from a probability distribution where values are iteratively generated, with the distribution of the next sample dependent only on the current sample value, and at each iteration, the candidate sample can be either accepted or rejected
A markov chain monte carlo (mcmc) method to obtain a sequence of random samples from a specified multivariate continuous probability distribution
Amount of money an insurer charges to provide the coverage described in the policy
Process used by insurers to calculate insurance rates, which drive insurance premiums
Amount of money needed to cover losses, expenses, and profit per one unit of exposure
A condition that results in an insurance claim
The cost to an insurer of payments to the insured and allocated loss adjustment expenses (alaes). overhead and profit are not included
Profit an insurer derives from providing coverage, excluding investment income
A type of rating plan that uses the insured's historical loss experience as part of the premium determination
A quantity, usually of money, that is exchanged for a good or service
A rate is the price, or premium, charged per unit of exposure. a rate is a premium expressed in standardized units.
The sum of losses divided by an exposure; it is also known as the pure premium.
A factor or percentage applied to the premium calculation to account for insurer profit in a policy
A factor calculated from the loss ratio method that calculates how the rates should change, with factors > 1 indicating an increase and vice versa
In a rate filing, the amount that the loss experience suggests that the insurer should charge to cover costs.
Weight assigned to observed data vs. that assigned to an external or broader-based set of data
Model assumption that the sample data comes from a population that can be modeled by a probability distribution with a fixed set of parameters
Line of business that insures against damage to their buildings and contents due to a covered cause of loss
Type of variable that can take on any real value
Process of determining premiums on the basis of likelihood of loss. insurance laws prohibit "unfair discrimination".
A rating factor, or rating variable, is a characteristic of the policyholder or risk being insured by which rates vary.
A rating factor, or rating variable, is a characteristic of the policyholder or risk being insured by which rates vary.
A variable that varies by groups or categories.
The difference of the expected risk between a specific level of a rating factor and an accepted baseline value. this difference may be arithmetic or proportional.

Suppose that y = c x, where x comes from a parametric distribution family and c is a positive constant. the distribution is said to be a scale distribution if (i) the distributions of y and x come from the same family and (ii) only a single parameter differs and that by a factor of c.
Exposure is based off policies written/issued
Exposure is based off amount exposed to loss for which coverage has been provided
Exposure amount for which coverage has not yet been provided
Exposure amount subject to loss at a particular point in time
Experience for rating is aggregated based on calendar year, as opposed to other methods such as when a policy term began
Date of loss occurrence that gives rise to a claim
Date when insurer is notified of the claim
A claim that has been reported but not yet closed
Different types of policies in an insurer's portfolio
Earned premium of historical policies using the current rate structure
Ratio of experience loss to on-level earned premium in the experience period
The amount paid to an individual or corporation for the recovery, under a policy of insurance, for loss that comes within that policy.
A claim is said to be incurred but not reported if the insured event occurs prior to a valuation date (and hence the insurer is liable for payment) but the event has not been reported to the insurer.
A claim is said to be closed when the company deems its financial obligations on the claim to be resolved.
A valuation date is the date at which a company summarizes its financial position, typically quarterly or annually.
This is the period between a policy's anniversary dates.
The gini index is twice the area between a lorenz curve and a 45 degree line.
45 degree line equating x and y, that represents a perfect alignment in the sample and population distribution
Statistical plot used to assess how close a data sample matches a theorized distribution

A concentration curve is a graph of the distribution of two variables, where both variables are ordered by only one of variables. for insurance applications, it is a graph of distribution of losses versus premiums, where both losses and premiums are ordered by premiums.
This generally refers to the premium principle where all risks pay the same amount.
Regulation that ensures consumers obtain fair and reasonable insurance prices and coverage
Government sets the entire rating system including coverages
Regulator must approve rates, forms, rules filed by insurers before use
Insurers may use new rates, forms, rules without approval from regulators
Insurers must file rates, forms, rules for record keeping and use immediately
Characteristics of a risk that help price the insurance contract
A rating method where each rating factor is the product of parameters associated with that rating factor
The distinguishing features of a policy that help determine the expected loss on the policy
Sum of expected losses and expenses and profit on a policy
A pricing structure that entices riskier individuals to purchase and discourages low-risk individuals from purchasing
Phenomenon where a book of business deteriorates as it attracts ever-riskier individuals when forced to increase premiums due to losses
Variables which the insurer has prior knowledge of before the policy inception
A mathematical expression that can be well defined with a formula that has a finite number of operations
Different outcomes of a categorical variable
A categorical variable where the categories do not have a natural order and any numbering is arbitrary
A variable that takes on a value of 0 or 1 to indicate the absence or presence of a categorical characteristic
Linear regression model where the response variable is the natural log of the expected response value
The categorical level chosen as the default with all dummy variable indicators of 0

A no-fault insurance system prescribed by state law where benefits are provided by an employer to an employee due to a job-related injury, including death, resulting from an accident or occupational disease
The unit of measurement chosen to represent the exposure for a particular risk
Natural log of the exposure amount that is added to a regression model to account for varying exposures
A table or list that contains the rating factors and associated premiums and other risk information
The timeframe during which a policy is active and the insurer is bound by the contractual obligation
Parameter in certain distributions, such as the exponential, that indicate how quickly the function decays, and it is the reciprocal of the scale parameter
The algebraic relationship between a dependent variable and explanatory variables
Relationship where the dependent variable is a product of the explanatory variables
The chosen set of rating categories where the rate equals the intercept of the model (the base value)
A numerical estimate of value in one category relative to the value in a base classification, typically expressed as a factor
Motorized vehicles which are not autos, such as atvs, off-road vehicles, go-carts, etc.
The manner in which a statistical distribution is parameterized

Matrix that measures the amount of information that an observable random variable x carries about an unknown parameter of a distribution, and is used to calculate covariance matrices of maximum likelihood estimators
A rating plan that uses an insured's risk characteristics to determine premium
The weight assigned to an insured's historical loss experience for the purposes of determining their premium in an experience rating plan
The remainder of the weight not assigned to an insured's historical loss experience in the experience rating plan
Average rate per exposure for an insured in a particular classification group
The threshold of experience necessary to assign 100% credibility to the insured's own experience
A credibility method that attempts to limit fluctuations in its estimates

Term: cumulative distribution function of the standard normal
Definition: Cumulative density function for the normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation 1
A credibility method that uses the amount of experience, expected value of the process variance, and variance of the hypothetical means to determine the credibility weight
The mean estimate of a risk when no loss information about the risk is known
The expected value of the conditional expected value of x given y is the same as the expected value of x
Parameter in a distribution whose value reflects the risk categorization

Term: expected value of the process variance
Definition: Average of the natural variability of observations from within each risk
Variance of the means across different classes, used to determine how similar or different the classes are from one another
An extension of the buhlmann credibility model that allows for varying exposure by year

A probability law that expresses conditional probability of the event a given the event b in terms of the conditional probability of the event b given the event a and the unconditional probability of a
A branch of statistics that leverages bayes theorem to update the distribution as more experience becomes available
A statistical model that assumes the frequency of claims is poisson whose mean has a prior distribution that is a gamma distribution
A situation where the bayesian credibility estimate matches that of the buhlmann credibility estimate
A statistical model for modeling the probability of an event using the binomial distribution with a probability that has a prior distribution from a beta distribution
Statistical method that allows the functional form of a fit from data to have no assumed prior distribution, constraints, or parameters
Credibility methods that estimate the credibility weight without using any assumptions about prior distributions or likelihoods, instead relying only on empirical data
Credibility method that assumes a distribution for the loss per exposure random variable and otherwise uses empirical data
A collection of contracts
A collection, or aggregation, of insurance contracts
A company that sells reinsurance
A rv is said to be heavy tailed if high probabilities are assigned to large values
One minus the distribution function. it gives the probability that a rv exceeds a specific value.
A risk measure that is is subadditive, monontonic, has positive homogeneity, and is translation invariant.
The expected value of a loss in excess of a quantity, given that the loss exceeds the quantity
A measure that summarizes the riskiness, or uncertainty, of a distribution
A risk measure based on a quantile function
A company that purchases reinsurance (also known as the reinsured)
Under an excess of loss arrangement, the insurer sets a retention level for each claim and pays claim amounts less than the level with the reinsurer paying the excess.
Insurance purchased by a non-insurer
An agreement between a reinsurer and a ceding company (also known as the reinsured) in which the reinsurer assumes a given percent of losses and premium

A proportional treaty where the reinsurer receives a flat percent of the premium for the book of business reinsured and pays a percentage of losses, including allocated loss adjustment expenses. the reinsurer may also pays the ceding company a ceding commission which is designed to reflect the differences in underwriting expenses incurred.
A company that purchases reinsurance (also known as the ceding company)
The amount of exposure that the the reinsured retains on a given line in a surplus share reinsurance agreement.
A function that maps the insurer portfolio loss into the amount of loss retained by the insurer.
Under a stop-loss arrangement, the insurer sets a retention level and pays in full total claims less than the level with the reinsurer paying the excess.

A proportional reinsurance treaty that is common in commercial property insurance. a surplus share treaty allows the reinsured to limit its exposure on any one risk to a given amount (the retained line). the reinsurer assumes a part of the risk in proportion to the amount that the insured value exceeds the retained line, up to a given limit (expressed as a multiple of the retained line, or number of lines).
A reinsurance contract that applies to a designated book of business or exposures.
A type of rating mechanism where insured premiums are adjusted based on their individual loss experience history
A type of experience rating where insureds obtain discounts on future years' premiums based on claims-free experience
Phenomenon where insureds under an experience rating system are dissuaded from filing minor claims in order to keep their no-claims discount
Co-operative system of reimbursement or repayment in case of loss as an insurance alternative
A stochastic model (time dependent) where the probability of each event depends only on the current state and not the historical path
Matrix that represents all probabilities for transition from one state to another (could be same state) for a markov chain
Probability distribution remains unchanged in the markov chain as time progresses
Irreducible markov chain where it is eventually possible to move from any state to any other state, with positive probability
A markov chain where there does not exist a probability distribution that allows for the chain to be walked backwards in time
A non-zero vector that changes by only a scalar factor when that linear transformation is applied
Probability of ending in a state j after n periods, starting in state i, where i and j can be the same state
After n transitions, the sum of variation between the probability in each state vs. the stationary probability
Type of regression model used for fitting data with an integral (count) response variable with mean equal to the variance
Type of regression model used for fitting data with an integral (count) response variable and can account for variance greater than the mean
Phenomenon where the variance of data is larger than what is modeled
Table that combines the effects of multiple rating classifications
Data that can be organized into a repository format, typically a database
Data that is not in a predefined format, most notably text, audio visual
Data which is non numerical in nature
Data which is numerical in nature
Data field with a natural ordering
Continuous data which is broken into interval bands with a natural ordering
Data storage method that stores amd finds records using a unique key hash
Data storage method that stores records by column instead of by row
Data storage method that uses the document metadata for search and retrieval, also known as semi-structured data
Corruption of data due to hardware failure in the storage device
Manual process of checking the integrity of data
Analysis of the format and definition of each field
Statistical analysis of the structured data present to detect irregularities
Statistics which are more unaffected by outliers or small departures from model assumptions
Approach to analyzing data sets to summarize their main characteristics, using visual methods, descriptive statistics, clustering, dimension reduction
Process used to challenge assumptions about the data through hypothesis tests, significance testing, model estimation, prediction, confidence intervals, and inference
Model that predicts a response target variable using explanatory predictors as input
Models that work with explanatory variables only to describe patterns or groupings
Supervised learning method where the response is a categorical variable
Supervised learning method where the response is a continuous variable
A measure of model complexity, typically based on the number of estimated parameters
Process where the modeling goal is to identify variables with meaningful and statistically significant relationships and test hypotheses
Process where the modeling goal is to predict new observations
Assumes data generated comes from a stochastic data model
Assumes data generated comes from unknown algorithmic models
Quantitative measure of how well the explanatory variables predict the response outcome
A program or sequence of instructions that is executed by another program
Modeling practice where data, code, analyses are published together in a manner so that others may verify the findings
Coding practice where documentation and code are written together
Governance process that details legal ownership of enterprise-wide data and outlines who has ability to create, edit, modify, share and restrict access to the data
Study of algorithms and statistical models that perform a specific task without using explicit instructions, relying on patterns and inference
Automated recognition of patterns and regularities in data
Process of collecting, cleaning, processing, analyzing, and discovering patterns and useful insights from large data sets
Dimension reduction technique that uses orthogonal transformations to convert a set of possibly correlated variables into a set of linearly uncorrelated variables
Unsupervised learning method that aims to splot data into homogenous groups using a similarity measure
Type of clustering that aims to partition data into k mutually exclusive clusters by assigning observations to the cluster with the nearest centroid
Supervised model that uses a linear function to approximate the relationship between the target and explanatory variables

Supervised model that generalizes linear regression by allowing the linear component to be related to the response variable via a link function and by allowing the variance of each measurement to be a function of its predicted value
The linear combination of explanatory variables component in a glm
Function that relates between the linear predictor component to the mean of the target variable
Modeling technique that uses a tree-like model of decisions to divide the sample space into non-overlapping regions to make predictions
A variable whose values are qualitative groups and can have no natural ordering (nominal) or an ordering (ordinal)
A variable is any characteristics, number, or quantity that can be measured or counted.
An ordinal variable with the additional property that the magnitudes of the differences between two values are meaningful
Data and information having an implicit or explicit association with a location relative to the earth
Data set is high dimensional when it has many variables. In many applications, the number of variables may be larger than the sample size.
This is a type of variable in which the measurement denotes membership in a set of groups, or categories
This is a type of qualitative/ categorical variable which has two or more categories without having any kind of natural order.
This is a type of qualitative/ categorical variable which has two or more ordered categories.
Is a special type of categorical variable where there are only two categories.
A quantitative variable is a type of variable in which numerical level is a realization from some scale so that the distance between any two levels of the scale takes on meaning.
A continuous variable is a quantitative variable that can take on any value within a finite interval.
Person in actual possession of insurance policy; policy owner.
A discrete variable is quantitative variable that takes on only a finite number of values in any finite interval.
A count variable is a discrete variable with values on nonnegative integers.
In a circular data, all values around the circle are equally likely. Example, imagine an analog picture of a clock.
An insurance company authorized to write insurance under the laws of any state.
Multivariate variable involves taking many measurements on a single entity.

Insurance that covers an employer's liability for injuries, disability or death to persons in their employment, without regard to fault, as prescribed by state or federal workers' compensation laws and other statutes.
Univariate analysis is the simplest form of analyzing data. “Uni” means “one”, so in other words your data has only one variable.

Missing data occur when no data value is stored for a variable in an observation. Missing data can occur because of nonresponse: no information is provided for one or more items or for a whole unit or subject.
Censored data have unknown values beyond a bound on either end of the number line or both. Here, the data is observed but the values (measurements) are not known completely.
Truncation occurs when values beyond a boundary are either excluded when gathered or excluded when analyzed. An object can be detected only if its value is greater than some number.

Stochastic process is defined as a collection of random variables that is indexed by some mathematical set, meaning that each random variable of the stochastic process is uniquely associated with an element in the set.

A deductible is a parameter specified in the contract. Typically, losses below the deductible are paid by the policyholder whereas losses in excess of the deductible are the insurer's responsibility (subject to policy limits and coninsurance).
Statistical dependence between the rankings of two variables
A statistic quantifying the strength of the association between two events, a and b, which is defined as the ratio of the odds of a in the presence of b and the odds of a in the absence of b
A statistical test of the goodness-of-fit between two models
A measure of the linear correlation between two variables
Pearson correlation, a measure of the linear correlation between two variables
A statistic used to measure the ordinal association between two measured quantities
An observation pair (x,y) is said to be concordant if the observation with a larger value of x has also the larger value of y
An observation pair (x,y) is said to be discordant if the observation with a larger value of x has the smaller value of y
A statistical test applied to sets of categorical data to evaluate how likely it is that any observed difference between the sets arose by chance
A technique for estimating the correlation between two theorised normally distributed continuous latent variables, from two observed binary variables
A technique for estimating the correlation between two theorised normally distributed continuous latent variables, from two observed ordinal variables
The correlation between two continuous variables with a bivariate normal distribution, where one variable is observed directly, and the other is unobserved
A correlation coefficient used when one variable is dichotomous
Transformed data which closely resemble a standard normal distribution
A multivariate distribution function with uniform marginals
A nonparametric measure of rank correlation
The probability distribution of the variables contained in the subset of a collection of random variables
A fat-tailed distribution is a probability distribution that exhibits a large skewness or kurtosis, relative to that of either a normal distribution or an exponential distribution
Any continuous variable can be mapped to a uniform random variable via its distribution function
The copulas of elliptical distributions
A table showing correlation coefficients between variables
Any member of a broad family of probability distributions that generalize the multivariate normal distribution
A measure of their comovements in the tails of the distributions
Bounds of multivariate distribution functions
A dependence measure based on the center of the distribution
Insurance purchased by an insurer

A deductible is a parameter specified in the contract. typically, losses below the deductible are paid by the policyholder whereas losses in excess of the deductible are the insurer's responsibility (subject to policy limits and coninsurance).

Coinsurance is an arrangement whereby the insured and insurer share the covered losses. typically, a coinsurance parameter specified means that both parties receive a proportional share, e.g., 50%, of the loss.

Pure premium is the total severity divided by the number of claims. it does not include insurance company expenses, premium taxes, contingencies, nor an allowance for profits. also called loss costs. some definitions include allocated loss adjustment expenses (alae).
The square-root of variance
Second central moment of a random variable x, measuring the expected squared deviation of between the variable and its mean
The sum of all claims observed in a period of time
50th percentile of a definition, or middle value where half of the distribution lies below
A graph of the proportion of a population on the horizontal axis and a distribution function of interest on the vertical axis.
A decomposition of the variance of a random variable into conditional components. specifically, for random variables x and y on the same probability space, var(x) = e[var(y|x)] + var[e(x|y)].
The expected value of a risk given that the risk exceeds a value-at-risk
Standard deviation divided by the mean of a distribution, to measure variability in terms of units of the mean
The sum of losses divided by the premium.
Risks that have the same distribution, that is, the distributions are identical.
Heterogeneous risks have different distributions. often, we can attribute differences to varying exposures or risk factors.
A type of rating variable that is so important that premiums and losses are often quoted on a "per exposure" basis. that is, premiums and losses are commonly standardized by exposure variables.
The amount of damages sustained by an individual or corporation, typically as the result of an insurable event.
Independent and identically distributed
Probability density function
Akaike's information criterion
Bayesian information criterion
Probability mass function
Markov Chain Monte Carlo
Cumulative distribution function
Degrees of freedom
Generalized linear model
Maximum likelihood estimate
Ordinary least squares
Probability function
Random variable
The time that elapses between the occurrence of the insured event and the reporting of this event to the insurance company.
The time between reporting and settlement of a claim.
Reported, But is Not fully Settled
Incurred in the past But is Not yet Reported. For such a claim the insured event took place, but the insurance company is not yet aware of the associated claim.
The claims handlers expert estimate of the outstanding amount on a claim.
Comma separated value file
Text file
Triangular display of loss reserve data. Accident or occurrence periods on one axis (often vertical) with development periods on the other (often horizontal). Also known as a development triangle.
Triangular display of loss reserve data. Accident or occurrence periods on one axis (often vertical) with development periods on the other (often horizontal). Also known as a run-off triangle.
Mean Squared Error of Prediction
An algorithm for predicting incomplete losses to their ultimate cumulative value. The name refers to the chaining of a sequence of (year-to-year development) factors into a ladder of factors.
weighted least squares
Generalized linear model
